para.paratext: There is a burden of persuasion as to each issue in the case, which is fixed by the pleadings[1] or by a pretrial order. The party with the burden of persuasion starts with the burden of producing evidence. Generally, the burden of persuasion will be on the plaintiff in a civil case[2] and on the prosecution in a criminal case.[3] The burden of producing evidence may shift during the trial in the case of an affirmative defense.

The case of Johnson v. Dodgen[4] involved a will contest with a caveat on the ground of monomania. The trial judge charged the jury that when the propounder established a prima facie case, the burden of coming forward with the evidence was on the caveator. The Georgia Supreme Court stated, “Instead of so charging the jury, the trial judge should have charged that the burden of proof shifted to the caveator.” The propounder failed to object to the charge so it was not reversible error. The better approach would have been to recognize the two issues, each with a burden of persuasion. The propounder has a burden of persuasion to establish the will. Then, the caveator has the burden of persuasion on the caveat an affirmative defense.

The Georgia Supreme Court answered a certified question from the Court of Appeals in the Burnette Ford cases[5] and established that the usual allocation of burdens is shifted on a motion for summary judgment. The evidence is construed most strongly against the movant when a party, who would not have the burden of persuasion in the trial of the case, moves for a summary judgment. In this situation, the party has the burden to show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact. While not a true burden of persuasion, it has much the same result.[6]

However, the circumstance can be somewhat different in criminal cases. For example, on a motion to suppress, the state still bears the burden of proving that the search was lawful even though the defendant is the movant.[7] The state also bears the burden of proving at a suppression hearing that the intoximeter test met the statutory requirements.[8] However, where the state produces evidence to have a defendant sentenced as a recidivist, the allocation of proof shifts to the defendant regarding the voluntariness of the pleas in nondeath penalty cases.[9] Likewise, the Supreme Court held that on habeas review, a defendant bears the burden of overcoming the presumption of regularity that attaches to a conviction and he, not the warden, has the burden of proving that a guilty plea was knowing, voluntary, and intelligent.[10]

In certain civil claims, the burden of producing evidence may shift repeatedly. For example, in Robinson v. Kroger,[11] the Georgia Supreme Court described the burden shifting scheme in a slip-and-fall case. In such actions, a plaintiff initially bears the burden of establishing that the defendant had actual or constructive knowledge of the hazard allegedly causing the fall. Once that burden is met, the burden of producing evidence then shifts to the defendant to establish the plaintiff's knowledge of the dangerous condition or his negligent failure to observe it, “i.e., that the plaintiff intentionally and unreasonably exposed [himself] to a hazard of which the plaintiff knew or, in the exercise of ordinary care, should have known.” If the defendant fails to meet this burden, the plaintiff has no further burden on this issue and need not address his own negligence. At that point, the only issue is of the defendant's negligence. If, however, the defendant does produce sufficient evidence to meet this burden, the plaintiff must reshoulder the burden of proving that he lacked knowledge of the hazard, despite the exercise of ordinary care, due to actions or conditions within the control of the owner/occupier.[12]

Another classic example of the burden shifting in civil cases can be found in discrimination cases. A Title VII plaintiff will be required to prove employment discrimination by proceeding under a standard burden-shifting framework.[13] Under this framework, the plaintiff bears the burden of establishing a prima facie case of discrimination, “the elements of which will vary depending upon the particular facts of the case and the nature of the alleged discrimination.”[14] If the plaintiff establishes his prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the employer to articulate a legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for the challenged employment decision. If the defendant carries this burden, then the burden shifts back to the plaintiff to prove that the articulated reason was really a pretext for discrimination.[15] This burden-shifting analysis also applies to whistleblower actions pursuant to the Georgia Whistleblower Act,[16] and to retaliation claims under the federal False Claims Act.[17]

In Combs v. Adair Mortg. Co., 245 Ga. 296, 264 S.E.2d 226 (1980), the court considered a certified question from the Court of Appeals. The question was: “Is the rule of Burnette Ford, Inc. v. Hayes, 227 Ga. 551, 181 S.E.2d 866 (1971), still in effect, or should the Court of Appeals apply Chambers v. Citizens & Southern Nat. Bank, 242 Ga. 498, 249 S.E.2d 214 (1978)?” The court answered the question by saying that the court would adhere to the ruling in the Burnette Ford case and that the Chambers case was the result of factual differences, applied in Combs v. Adair Mortg. Co., 155 Ga. App. 432, 270 S.E.2d 828 (1980); Aiken v. Drexler Shower Door Co., Inc., 155 Ga. App. 436, 270 S.E.2d 831 (1980); Waller v. Transworld Imports, Inc., 155 Ga. App. 438, 271 S.E.2d 1 (1980).

The Combs case was followed in Tri-Cities Hospital Authority v. Sheats, 247 Ga. 713, 279 S.E.2d 210 (1981), where the court stated: “only in cases where there is a direct contradiction in the testimony of the respondent as to a material issue of fact will that party's unfavorable testimony be taken against him.”
See Fiumefreddo v. Scudder, 252 Ga. 279, 313 S.E.2d 683 (1984), in regard to the burden on a motion for summary judgment.

There is still a problem on motions for summary judgment. In Charles Rossignol, Inc. v. Prophecy Corp., 177 Ga. App. 245, 339 S.E.2d 288 (1985), the court considered the question of contradiction in the testimony of the respondent. The majority did not follow Tri-Cities Hospital Auth. v. Sheats, which the dissent said was controlling. On certiorari, the Supreme Court affirmed, Prophecy Corp. v. Charles Rossignol, Inc., 256 Ga. 27, 343 S.E.2d 680 (1986). Although the Tri-Cities Hospital case was not considered, it is now questionable. The court held that, where a deposition and affidavit are contradictory but a reasonable explanation of the contradiction is offered in the affidavit, the favorable portion of the respondent's testimony is not to be construed against him.

In Gentile v. Miller, Stevenson, & Steinichen, Inc., 257 Ga. 583, 361 S.E.2d 383 (1987), the court considered the question as to whether the rule of the Prophecy Corp. case, supra, would have the same ultimate effect when applied to a movant for summary judgment as it has upon a respondent. The question was answered in the affirmative.

In Travick v. Lee, 278 Ga. App. 823, 825–826, 630 S.E.2d 99 (2006), the Prophecy holding was further clarified. Therein, the Court of Appeals explained that “[a]lthough we construe the evidence most favorably to appellant as the party opposing the motion for summary judgment, where there is a direct contradiction in the testimony of the respondent as to a material issue of fact, that party's unfavorable testimony will be taken against him.” Inasmuch, “Prophecy and its progeny are applicable only to the testimony of a party to the litigation. ‘[O]ur precedent has remained clear that the rule applies only to the testimony of parties to a case, and not to the testimony of witnesses who are not parties. Likewise, the Court of Appeals has declined to extend the Prophecy rule to anything other than the testimony of a party or a party witness.’”
See also Thompson v. Ezor, 272 Ga. 849, 852–853, 536 S.E.2d 749 (2000), wherein the Georgia Supreme Court declined to apply the Prophecy rule to nonparty expert witness.

In Travelers Home and Marine Ins. Co. v. Castellanos, 297 Ga. 174, 773 S.E.2d 184 (2015), the Supreme Court held that the insured bore the burden in responding to a summary judgment motion to prove that the liability insurer legally denied coverage to the tortfeasor for failure to cooperate.
